channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kenosha Shooting: NBA Cancels Thursday's Games
item.description: The teams were among 14 Major League Baseball squads that chose not to play on Thursday as protests over the shooting of Jacob Blake continued.
item.media:credit: Brad Penner/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: New York Mets third baseman J.D. Davis, left, and first baseman Dominic Smith walked off the field in protest before a scheduled game against the Miami Marlins on Thursday.

item.title: Hurricane Laura Live News and Updates
item.description: After landfall overnight with 150 m.p.h. winds, Laura ripped northward. Officials confirmed at least six deaths tied to the storm, and hundreds of thousands of people have lost power.
item.media:credit: Javier Fernandez for The New York Times

item.title: How Chaos in Kenosha Is Already Swaying Some Voters in Wisconsin
item.description: As residents see fires and looting, some worry that local Democratic leaders are failing to keep control of the situation.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Ellen Almer Durston
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covering the windows of a damaged business in Kenosha on Tuesday, where protests over the shooting of Jacob Blake gave way to looting in some instances.

item.title: ‘2020 Can Go to Hell’: The Story Behind the Viral Fire Photo That Said It All
item.description: Pandemic, unemployment, wildfire — Lake Berryessa, Calif., has seen it all this year. A photo from the town that evoked the trauma of 2020 sped across the internet. Here, though, it was real life.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris Lacombe looked over the remains of his home, which was destroyed by the L.N.U. Lightning Complex, in Spanish Flat, Calif.

item.title: Hurricane Laura Carves Destructive Path Across Louisiana
item.description: Although the storm surge was less than projected, Laura was responsible for at least six deaths and extensive property damage.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Manny Fernandez and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: In coastal Cameron Parish, La., search-and-rescue helicopters flew low over Holly Beach on Thursday.

item.title: Suspect in Kenosha Killings Lionized the Police
item.description: Kyle Rittenhouse, accused of killing two people during protests of a police shooting, faces six criminal counts. His social media accounts showed strong support for officers.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Pat Nabong/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kyle Rittenhouse is accused of killing two people during a protest in Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday. Earlier in the day, he was among volunteers cleaning graffiti off a school.

item.title: Trump Heads Into General Election Leading a Party He Has Transformed
item.description: After three days of law-and-order rhetoric at the Republican convention, President Trump was ready to make a determined push to change the subject from the coronavirus and to mark Joseph R. Biden Jr. as a willing partner of the far left.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump has made appearances every night of the convention, and many of his family members have made speeches.

item.title: Instead of Evolving as President, Trump Has Bent the Job to His Will
item.description: In a 40-minute phone call this week, Mr. Trump struggled to describe how he has changed in office. “I think I’ve just become more guarded than I was four years ago,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: President Trump heads into the fall campaign with a striking blend of braggadocio and grievance.

item.title: C.D.C.’s ‘Clarification’ on Coronavirus Testing Offers More Confusion
item.description: After saying that those exposed to the virus need not get tested, the agency’s director clarified that “testing may be considered” for those people.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert R. Redfield, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, sought to clarify the agency’s recommendations regarding testing.

item.title: N.B.A. ‘Boycott’ or Strike: What’s the Difference?
item.description: Professional athletes in several leagues protested racial injustice by refusing to play on Wednesday, leaving fans with some legal questions. We asked the experts.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The Milwaukee Bucks refused to participate in an N.B.A. playoff game on Wednesday, setting off a protest that spread to other leagues.

item.title: The World Outside
item.description: Beyond the R.N.C.’s walls, things haven’t slowed down.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Black Lives Matter supporters during demonstrations following the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wis.

item.title: Despite the virus, Trump will speak in front of a large crowd, seated closely together on the South Lawn.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Workers set up for President Trump’s speech on the South Lawn of the White House.

item.title: How to Help Hurricane Laura Victims
item.description: These organizations are providing relief in Texas and Louisiana, and tips on how to evaluate charities.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.media:description: Latasha Myles and Howard Anderson surveyed damage to their living room, where they were sitting when winds from Hurricane Laura ripped the roof off their home in Lake Charles, La., at about 2:30 a.m. on Thursday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Hurricane Laura tore through part of the U.S. already struggling with the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Is Ivanka Trump Going to Change Anyone’s Mind?
item.description: Four years ago, the would-be first daughter was seen by some to have the power to persuade moderate women voters and to rein in her own father’s impulses. A lot is different now.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump, the president’s eldest daughter, declared that she is a “proud Trump Republican” this year, removing guesswork that she was trying to have a moderating influence on her father’s conservative positions.

item.title: RNC What to Watch For: President Trump, Ivanka Trump, Dana White to Speak
item.description: On the final night of the Republican National Convention, President Trump will deliver his acceptance speech from the White House’s South Lawn. He’s expected to deliver a blistering denunciation of his rival, Joe Biden.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: The South Lawn of the White House, where President Trump will make his speech accepting the Republican renomination on Thursday.

item.title: No Bushes, Reagans, Cheneys or McCains: Who Is Missing at Trump’s R.N.C.
item.description: The old guard that led the Republican Party from 1980 until 2016 has been conspicuously absent from this year’s convention, representing the final signature on the party’s bitter divorce.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: President Trump and Melania Trump at Fort McHenry in Baltimore on Wednesday for the Republican convention. Many former party leaders have not been invited, or have stayed away.

item.title: ‘Do Not Vote for My Dad’: When Families Disagree on Politics
item.description: Conventional wisdom has long held that the most powerful political influence on any child are the parents. New research suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

item.title: Hurricane Laura Topples Confederate Statue That Survived Protests
item.description: Officials voted two weeks ago to keep the monument on courthouse property in Lake Charles, La., but Hurricane Laura toppled its statue from the base.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hurricane Laura damaged the South’s Defenders Memorial Monument, which has toppled in other storms but always been restored. Critics hope this time will be different.

item.title: Officer Implicated in Kenosha Shooting Is on the Department’s Bike Squad
item.description: A seven-year veteran, Rusten Sheskey has said he sees the value of doing “public relations” on the job.
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Brian Passino/The Kenosha News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Officer Rusten Sheskey of the Kenosha Police Department.

item.title: Rudy Giuliani, who went from America’s mayor to the president’s personal lawyer, will speak Thursday night.
item.media:description: Rudy Giuliani talking to reporters at the White House in July. Mr. Giuliani will speak during a prime slot at the Republican National Convention on Thursday.

item.title: Laura Hits Petrochemical Region, and a Factory Goes Up in Flames
item.description: The hurricane rolled over a coast studded with oil, gas and chemical plants. Other storms have caused the release of toxic substances, often affecting minority communities.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Photo by William Widmer for The New York Times

item.title: White House Wants Companies to Foot Payroll Tax Bill for Workers
item.description: The Treasury Department has not been willing to issue guidance making it clear that companies will be on the hook for deferred taxes, further delaying crucial information for businesses.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s executive order to defer payroll taxes has prompted a debate within the administration over who should ultimately pay.

item.title: The pandemic has curbed new voter registrations, but a study suggests a reason for hope.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: New voter registrations have plummeted this year, thanks to the coronavirus pandemic, despite heightened interest in the election.

item.title: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Rooting for More Violence’ Amid Kenosha Unrest
item.description: As Republicans sensed a political opportunity, the Democratic nominee sought to turn attention back to the pandemic and highlighted the president’s tendency to inflame volatile situations.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Thomas Kaplan and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday criticized the president’s response to the unrest in Kenosha, Wis.: “And what’s he doing? He’s kept pouring gasoline on the fire.”

item.title: Israeli Officer Need Not Have Shot Autistic Palestinian, Commander Says
item.description: The commander testified that the man his partner killed, Iyad al-Hallaq, was not resisting and posed no danger, in a case that ignited protests against police brutality.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Wisam Hashlamoun/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A mural for Iyad al-Hallaq, who was killed by an Israeli policeman while on his way to school in May.

item.title: Jared Kushner, a real estate scion, says boycotting N.B.A. players have the ‘luxury’ to ‘take a night off from work.’
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: R.N.C. Skims Over Trump’s ‘Unfinished Business’ in Foreign Policy
item.description: From Iran to North Korea, President Trump has failed to achieve many of his stated foreign policy goals. He is asking for a second term to get them done.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump is making a pitch that he requires a second term to make good on his grandest foreign policy ambitions.

item.title: The R.N.C.’s TV ratings declined on the third night, lagging the D.N.C.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: The third night of the Republican convention drew about 17.3 million live TV viewers.

item.title: Bush’s ethics lawyer calls for an investigation of Pompeo’s R.N.C. speech.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes

item.title: In Trump’s Gilded Beltway, Rudy Giuliani Finds a Potent Reward: Relevance
item.description: No one has seized the chance for a second act under President Trump with more gusto than Mr. Giuliani, whose epic career of ups and downs, feuds and outrages, has made him in some ways the quintessential creature of Trump’s Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.media:description: Rudy Giuliani talking to reporters at the White House in July. Mr. Giuliani, who has had a career of ups and downs, will speak during a prime slot at the Republican National Convention on Thursday.

item.title: Conway says the more violence erupts, ‘the better it is’ for Trump’s re-election prospects.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s counselor and his 2016 campaign manager, addressed the Republican convention on Wednesday.

item.title: Deceptive robocalls try to frighten Detroit residents about voting by mail.
item.description: The calls suggest that voting-by-mail exposes personal information, a lie, in what officials said was an apparent effort to suppress vote
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

item.title: Reopened Schools Find Health Risks in Water After Covid-19 Lockdowns
item.description: A number of schools found the bacteria that causes Legionnaires’ disease in their water, and experts say more should expect to see it.
item.dc:creator: Max Horberry
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Experts worry that water was left to stagnate in plumbing during lockdown, and that schools don’t have plans or effective guidance for dealing with the effects of prolonged shutdowns.

item.title: Trump will appear at a live ‘town hall’ with undecided voters on ABC next month.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

item.title: Dennis Williams, Former U.A.W. Leader, Is Accused of Conspiracy
item.description: The ex-president of the United Auto Workers was charged with using union funds for personal expenses. The case is part of a long federal investigation.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette and Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: Federal prosecutors have accused Dennis Williams, a former president of the United Auto Workers, of using union funds to pay for personal expenses.

item.title: Citing Kenosha, a Wisconsin college cancels plans for Pence to deliver its commencement address.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cooper
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence delivering his speech to the Republican convention from Fort McHenry in Baltimore on Wednesday.

item.title: Pelosi says Biden should not debate Trump. Biden disagrees.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos, Emily Cochrane, Thomas Kaplan and Michael Cooper
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. said, “He’s rooting for more violence, not less, and is clear about that. And what’s he doing? He’s kept pouring gasoline on the fire. This happens to be Donald Trump’s America.”

item.title: Here’s What America’s Covid-Era Classrooms Look Like
item.description: We asked educators to show us how they are preparing their classrooms to teach amid the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wise

item.title: Here’s how to watch as the convention wraps up.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: In Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, cracks emerge in a pro-Trump wall.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rod Nelson, a retired C.E.O. of Mackinac Straits Health, is a lifelong Republican. But he will be voting for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee, this year.

item.title: Dozens of former McCain and Romney staff members back Biden.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Zach Gibson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator John McCain at the Capitol in 2017.

item.title: Ted Cruz didn’t get a convention invite, but he still has plenty to say.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ted Cruz, who is not an R.N.C. speaker, is sticking with his ideological conservatism.

item.title: Hurricane Laura in Pictures
item.description: Photographers are on the ground in Texas and Louisiana documenting the damage from the storm.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times

item.title: The G.O.P. argues that only Trump can stop the chaos. But he’s already in charge.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence said Wednesday that “we will have law and order on the streets of this country for every American of every race and creed and color.”

item.title: ‘At no time before have voters faced a clearer choice,’ Trump will say in his convention address.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cooper and Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: President Trump will accept the Republican nomination from the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Some of the immigrants Trump naturalized on Tuesday didn’t know they were being broadcast.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Donald Trump takes part in a US Naturalizations Ceremony at the White House.

item.title: How Trump’s convention has become a crucial play for the suburbs.
item.description: Conciliatory messages at the Republican convention were an acknowledgment by the president’s campaign that appealing to his right-wing base will not be enough to win re-election.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters, Annie Karni and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Voter opinions about President Trump have been remarkably impervious to the good and bad news about him, fluctuating little since he took office.
